Award.AwardTitle: Digitization PEN: Digitization of North American Bryophyte and Lichen Specimens from Two Ohio Herbaria at the University of Cincinnati (CINC)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project joins the ongoing Thematic Collections Network project "North American Lichens and Bryophytes: Sensitive Indicators of Environmental Quality and Change". The project will contribute label data for approximately 107,000 specimens form North America. Both herbaria included in this PEN are especially rich in 18th to early 20th Century collections which will fill an important gap in attaining the TCN's goals. These organisms are known to be highly sensitive to environmental changes and, accordingly this data, will support future research on environmental changes during this period of history which may influence distributional patterns of lichens and bryophytes over time. Other research projects, that use map-based analyses of historical vs. present-day data, could address questions such as, can these hyper-sensitive organisms be used as early warning bioindicators to highlight the early causes and effects of environmental change? In addition, exposure of these historical specimens and their data will be useful for studies of changes in the local vegetation.

The results of this project will be useful to society by increasing our understanding and our ability for early detection of the causal factors and resulting patterns of environmental quality including, for example, changes in air and water quality. This project will provide experience in museum curation and database management to undergraduate and graduate students. Outreach will include design and implementation of pre-K and 1st grade activities to introduce young students to new colors, textures of the strange and interesting things in the natural world, and the idea that all organisms are important. This award is made as part of the National Resource for Digitization of Biological Collections through the Advancing Digitization of Biological Collections program and all data resulting from this award will be available through the National Resource (iDigBio.org).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit - Herbaria are important historical repositories of scientific information obtained from their pressed plant specimens collected decades or even centuries ago from many locations all around the world. Unfortunately, these plants and the information they contain on their labels are typically inaccessible, being only available to researchers who physically visit the herbarium. In an effort to make these data accessible to all, herbarium specimens are now being imaged with the corresponding data deposited into online repositories. Although many large national herbaria have been imaging and databasing their specimens for some time, important regional collections in other herbaria often lag behind. Thus, the overall goal of this project was to record in a database all of the North American bryophyte and lichen samples held at herbaria at the University of Cincinnati (acronym: CINC) and Miami University (MU). This was accomplished by imaging the label on each herbarium specimen, analyzing it with character recognition software to automatically parse the label information into a database, and then editing the resulting data for accuracy.  All data were then uploaded to public data repositories for dissemination.

As a direct output of this grant, we have successfully imaged and made publicly accessible the data obtained from labels of 100,594 herbarium specimens from the University of Cincinnati (CINC) and Miami University in Ohio (MU). This consists of 36,382 bryophyte specimens and 7,017 lichen specimens at CINC and 48,753 bryophyte specimens and 8,442 lichen specimens at MU. Of these, 5.1% and 56.4% of entries of the CINC and MU specimens have already been edited and corrected in the database; citizen scientist volunteers are currently working to finish the remainder. As a direct result of these efforts, loan requests are now being received, and the data deposited into online repositories is actively being used in research projects by other investigators.  To date, data from CINC database have been incorporated into several peer-reviewed publications.

Broader Impacts - A secondary goal of this project was to increase awareness of the value of herbaria and foster in students and the local community an interest in plants, natural history collections, and curatorial activities. During the granting period, 17 undergraduate students and 1 graduate student received training in digitization and herbarium curation techniques. Of these, 8 were women (44%) with 2 students from underrepresented groups (of Hispanic and Middle Eastern origin). One of these students, a Secondary Education, Life Sciences major, created instructional lesson plans targeting 7-12 grades on the topics of “Women in Science: the Braun sisters”, “Plant Evolution – cladograms”, and “Dichotomous Keys”.  These will be made available via sharemylesson.com.  We also partnered with the Cincinnati Nature Center to lead a workshop module for K-8 teachers on “The Schoolyard Stomp – Exploring Plant Diversity Around Our Schools” to learn how to identify plant species within school yards.  In addition, citizen scientists from the local community, including members of the Cincinnati Zoo and Botanical Garden, the Wild Ones, and the Cincinnati Wildflower Preservation Society, also helped to edit the data base.  Community outreach projects included the STEM Girls Day Out event, a collaboration between CINC and the Cincinnati Museum Center. At this event focusing on UC Women in Ecology, 32 girls and their families visited CINC to learn about E. Lucy Braun and Annette Braun, two formidable women who spent their entire careers at UC in the early to mid 1900’s.  STEM Girls also collected and identified plants in their community by preparing pressed herbarium specimens.  All these events actively engaged students, teachers, and the general public to better appreciate the diversity and role of plants in our world today.

 


Last Modified: 09/29/2017
Modified by: Theresa M Culley

All data were then uploaded to public data repositories for dissemination. This consists of 36,382 bryophyte specimens and 7,017 lichen specimens at CINC and 48,753 bryophyte specimens and 8,442 lichen specimens at MU. All these events actively engaged students, teachers, and the general public to better appreciate the diversity and role of plants in our world today.
